This hotel was exactly what I was looking for:
- Medium priced (not budget, but not expensive)
- Modern, spacious rooms
- Great location in the heart of downtown
- Friendly Memphis service
- Interesting historic property (1927) with art deco touches in lobby
- Well maintained
- Valet parking not cheap ($16/day) but typical for major downtown hotels. Offsite self-parking available for less (check with front desk)
Personally, I thought it was great.
See photos.

Went last month with my wife to see a show and enjoy some fine dining. Colin and the staff took great care of us and made some great recommendations during our stay. Our room was clean and a generous size considering some of the other places i have stayed in NYC. For the price there is not a better deal in the city -will definitely being going back soon.

I spent LOTS of time reading reviews here, and thankfully, there were good reviews about this hotel, and location was one of the top priorities for this trip.
We were happy with our room rate, although we booked rather last minute, and the only type of room available was a king bed with a sleeper sofa. This was not my 1st pref. but we just put the kids on the sleeper sofa. We were only there for one night. Yes, the valet charge was a bummer, and the only thing I noticed was that it took them a long time to move our car from the street in front of the hotel to wherever they store them.
The room was fairly clean and quiet. The lobby is very pretty and the staff was friendly and helpful. They gave the kids "goodie bags" when we first checked in. We didn't let the kids open them until we were in for the night.
The conceirge at the hotel was wonderful. I spoke with her A LOT about everything and she had answers for everything and she was very elegant and treated us with respect and she was very sweet with the children. You could tell she enjoys her job.
She recommended several places for dinner and we ended up choosing a restaurant called Jones. (Jones-restaurant) It was a very hip retro style restaurant with GREAT food. They have no kids menu specified, but they could order selections from an adult entree and they would just bring part of it. But some things on the menu were very kid friendly. My daughter had tomato soup and a grilled cheese sandwich. My son had fried chicken and french fries - his portion was a bit large. My other daughter had grilled cheese and chips. See photos of food.
The hotel is within walking distance of many sight seeing things from a historical perspective. We happened to be in the right place at the right time and were near liberty plaza during an open house of independence hall, so we did not have to wait and get tickets etc. The tour guide was awesome. He was a great communicator and very knowlegable and easy to hear and understand. He involved the children and kept their attention.
We also splurged on a 20 min. horse and buggy ride through the historic district. This was great because they are not just letting you ride and look, they give you a running commentary on the history and they know lots of little neat tidbits of info that you may not have known or they point out things you may not have noticed. I wish we would have paid for a longer tour. We paid $30 for 20 min. There was a sign that said tips were appreciated, so I tipped $5. My kids were thrilled because this is something they would like to do in NYC, and we never have, so it was a treat.
The new visitors center is awesome and the gift shops all around are great. The one at the Betsy Ross house and the National parks building are 2 we visited. If you have lots of money to spare, there are adorable historical dolls for purchase at the National parks gift shop. Ben Franklin, and other colonial looking dolls. They start at like $90 each, though. I wish I would have splurged on one, because they were beautifully made. But, no, I did not.
However, we never made it to the Rittenhouse square area, shopping area or other areas in the city. But having never been there, I'm not sure what I was missing. Our location was close enough that we could walk down to Penn's Landing.
The Liberty Bell was great. The display for it now is beautiful. It's cool to see Independence Hall behind it through the window when you are inside looking at it.
Also, a couple of doors down on the block of the hotel entrance there is a tiny shop that sells ice cream and water ice (slushees). On the opposite corner there is a COSI. We went to both places.
If you are there with kids to see the historical things, I would highly recommend this hotel. I booked over the phone with the hotel "headquarters," and they were careful to ask about what type of view and what floor in addition to smoking or non, beds, etc. If we return we will stay there.

The hotel is blocks away from Times Square and close train. It is an older hotel but its price and location out weigh any unnecessary amenities of a more updated and costly hotel. It is perfect for sleeping which is the only thing you should do in a great city such as NY.

These people are amazing! I consider myself a difficult customer and they always go above and beyond. I always leave happy! They are especially helpful about scheduling they are so accommodating. This is my third time here and ingot Christmas nails. So cute! I always go to Mimi! Such a sweetheart.

I saw this film at the Sundance Film Festival and I too was surprised that it didn't generate more notice because it was not only powerful and beautifully crafted but very original. The audience was totally engaged and the greatest part of seeing a film like this at a festival is the opportunity to talk to the director and cast in the Q&A session afterward. They literally had to throw us out of the screening room for the next film - we could have gone on for a lot longer. The film is thought provoking and hilarious at the same time. It will be a shame if this film isn't picked up for wider distribution - I hope it will at least become available on DVD because I want to see it again and share it with everyone I know.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel for our annual anniversary vacation. The view was beautiful and the furniture was comfy! The staff were so helpful and polite. When they heard it was our anniversary, they sent us a bottle of champagne for free! I would definitely recommend it to anyone.

This was the second of three films that Irving Berlin wrote for the Astaire-Rogers franchise and it has by far the largest score and is somewhat unusual in that two of the numbers are performed by Harriet Hilliard leaving the rest to be divvied and/or shared between the principals. As usual the storyline needn't detain us though for the record it was based on a play, Shore Leave, that also served as the basis for a Broadway Musical, Hit The Deck. Anyone who actually saw Shore Leave in the theatre may have been momentarily bemused inasmuch as the roles played by Fred and Ginger were created for the movie but what matters, as always, is the music, lyrics and hoofing and this is all out of the right bottle. It's a departure from the other titles in the franchise in that 1) we get to see Astaire play the piano - in real life he was an accomplished pianist and composed several songs, one of which, I'm Building Up To An Awful Let-Down, had a lyric by Johnny Mercer and spent a couple of weeks in the charts - and it is the only one of the series in which he played a serviceman, albeit an ex-hoofer who enlisted in the navy after being dumped by dancing partner Ginger before the story starts. He gets to perform a little-known but excellent Berlin number, I'd Rather Lead A Band as well as duetting on I'm Putting All My Eggs In One Basket but the ultimate number is the prophetic - in 1936 rumbles of World War II were already being felt - Let's Face The Music And Dance, one of the most potent ballads ever performed by the team. So what if Randolph Scott is a little wooden and fish-out-of-water without either a horse or a six-gun within easy reach and Harriet Hilliard doesn't exactly set the screen on fire; we came to see Fred and Ginger and the only question is, do they deliver. Answer: In spades.

My boyfriend and I stayed here for 2 nights and had a great experience. Loved the location, so many sites, restaurants, and stores within walking distance. Also the verizon center is right around the corner and we were there to watch a hockey game. Our room was small the our view was an alley way but the room itslef was clean and very modern. I loved thow te hotel has been decorated. Breakfast is cleaned up and put away promptly at 10am so we missed it both mornings:( Other than missing out on the free breakfast we were very happy at this hotel.

The submarine used was NOT Varangian! 'It' was in fact two boats, P614 and P615, both built for Turkey by Vickers Armstorng at Barrow-in-Furness but kept hold of by the Royal Navy for the duration of the war. P615 was sunk but P614 was eventually delivered in 1945. The confusion no doubt arose because someone looked up P61 (as I did) and found Varangian! When in fact, the last digit of both P614 and P615 was in fact just painted out....There are some extremely realistic moments in the film. These Turkish boats were very similar to the S-class. As no S-class submarines survive, the shots of them (as P61) and of the depot ship "Forth" form part of an interesting record now, as well as an excellent film.

I've avoided seeing this film for some time but finally picked up a copy. Having been born too late to see 'Hair' in its contemporary setting, I have just been familiar with the UK and Broadway cast recordings for many years; and saw it on stage in the late 1980s where it looked a little creaky but still, great fun.The film. It drops some of the songs (The Bed, My Conviction, Frank Mills) and cuts others (Walking in Space). However, what is left is presented very well indeed. All the singers and dancers are excellent, and the key performers (especially Treat Williams as Berger, Beverley D'Angelo as Sheila, John Savage as Claude) are memorable.As a hippy celebration and anthem, 'Hair' manages to be remain potent even in a film made ten years too late. It was no longer the era of peace, love, and Biba, but the time of punk rock ... although watching this film now, in the time of Iraqi problems, gives a new resonance to the Vietnam issues of the 1960s.Milos Forman, who also made 'Amadeus', did a good job on directing. In its scope and feel it reminds me of Norman Jewison's 'Jesus Christ Superstar', especially with the joy of the 'Aquarius' scene and the intimacy of 'Easy To Be Hard'.I really enjoyed this film and consider it a good representation of a musical born out of the first truly hedonistic era.

As for the room - we ended having a closet door removed because of a broken mirror. There were black scuff marks on the wall paper and the covers on the baseboard heaters were bent out of shape in several areas.
We had a corner suite with a kitchen, full size fridge, dining area, microwave, 2 cooking units with dishes and utensils and a few cooking supplies. There was a flat screen TV in the living area and bedroom. It was a very large suite considering we were in the middle of downtown Chicago.

This is the most confronting documentary I have ever seen. It was a simple and breathtaking view of a beautiful idea. Based on photographs of the hidden industrial landscapes centred around the modern industrial growth of China, Edward Burtynsky brings to life confronting issues that we so easily chose to ignore.Taking no political sides, this movie is a neutral moving picture of realities that our western societies chooses not to educate us about - the by-products of economical growth, the externalities paid by citizens of the lesser-developed communities, the source of our comforts and the wastes of our consumer lifestyles.Amazing, heart-breaking, impossible to ignore. This is a challenging journey but one worth taking - please stop staying ignorant and at least see these photographs of truth without feeling any pressure to take a standing to these issues. 10/10 definitely!

I've stayed here twice now and haven't been disappointed. It's very clean, the bed is comfortable, and the view from my window overlooking times square is great! Last time I was here over mother's day weekend, my daughter and I ordered room service as we got in late and were exhausted. I was impressed with the quality. I stayed at this hotel on business for a few days in May 2008 and I really enjoyed my stay. Upon arriving, my room was not ready yet since I got there rather early, and the front desk person was super helpful and arranged for my bags to be stored and took my cell phone number to alert me when my room was ready. He also recommended a place around the corner for lunch which was very good. I was barely through my lunch and he called to let me know my room was ready, it was very quick. I was impressed because being cynical, I did not expect anyone to call, but they did, and very promptly and politely I should add!
So I returned to the hotel after lunch and retrived my bags and finished checking in. My room was at the end of a long corridor and faced the rear of the hotel. The room was really nice, I enjoyed it. My two "complaints", and I wouldn't even call them that, were the noise of the "El" train, even though i was on the 20th floor, I still heard it loud and clear every few minutes - it sounded like a strong wind blowing, that is what kept coming to mind. It didn't interrupt my sleep but I can see how it would effect some people's sleep overall. I found it soothing because I like "white noise" when I sleep. But, I wish now that I had asked for a front-facing room (those cost more I think, however). My other issue was the bathroom door which is set up to automatically close - it cannot stay open on its own. It's annoying! A colleague who was also staying at the hotel said she rigged it by opening it all the way and then opening the closet door so that the bathroom door could not close. I did this too and it helped - of course I closed the door when I needed to, but also I was in the room alone so I wanted to shower with the door open to relieve the steam. Lastly, speaking of the shower, and maybe this is just me, I had no idea how to turn it on, ha! I thought you would just turn the handle and the water would come on, but on this one you have to PULL the handle out and then turn. It did not say this anywhere so I thought the handle was broken and actually called maintenance - I was embarassed when they told me I simply had to pull the handle first. It sounded like they had heard this before, or at least I am going to tell myself that!
Overall, a beautiful hotel with a friendly staff, in a great location in Chicago's Loop. Lots of little cafes and stores nearby - convenient for little necessities or sundries. I would absolutely stay there again without hesitation!

One of my favourite spots for beer in Montreal. An ever changing menu (picked from the best local breweries), good food, and a great atmosphere make this place a sure-bet for a good time.

The beer menu is usually around 30-40 beers, and written on a blackboard (it changes daily). With beers from MTL, Dieu Du Ciel, and other big local names, you just can't go wrong. There's always a few strange/fruity ones on there, as well as a cider or two, so there's guaranteed to be something for everyone. You can also get smaller 'taster' sized glasses, which is great for trying a large number of beers (and still being able to walk)

The back patio section is now open, but I haven't had a chance to try it myself. The place itself is alongside a public park, which gives it a look of plenty of space out the back.

We stayed here over the weekend as tourists of Philadelphia. The location of the hotel is great, just a short walk to the Independence Park, and right in the heart of the museum district. We had a great view out our window of the Logan Square and the Art Museum. The Hotel staff was really great. We had a small mix up with out reservation at checkin, but the front desk compensated us very graciously for this mistake. The resturauant had an excellent breakfast buffet each day, with custom omelettes and the works. Our room was very comfortable, and well equipped with comfort items. Overall this hotel is a very good choice.

My trip started poorly when my flight got canceled because of maintenance issues and I had to spend six hours in the airport. Arrived in El Paso late, and when I checked in the staff at the check-in counter told me they did not have the room that I had reserved available (king size bed), but they were willing to give me a complimentary upgrade to a room. Intriguing... Then the other shoe dropped. The "upgraded room" was a two double size beds. I told her the "upgrade" sure didn't seem like an upgrade, and that I preferred a room with a king size bed. As if it were almost scripted she said, "but it is a very spacious room." I stood my ground and she miraculously found a king size room, but it was a handicapped room. She said, "the big drawback is there is no tub." I can't remember the last time I soaked in a bathtub. She gave me the key to the room, and off I went. Not a big deal, but it almost seemed like she didn't want me in the king size room.
In regards to the hotel, the property is pretty dated and the rooms show signs of wear and tear after 20 years. My room is extremely large and comfortable. In spite of being next door to the airport, you can barely hear the planes coming and going. Many restaurants are within walking distance. I didn't mind the sleep number bed, but I was exhausted.
There are a couple different promotions out there if you join the "Carlson Club" before you make your reservation. Do an internet search and see if you can earn extra points or a free stay.

I just came home from this place and I can finally say I have found my permanent ramen place in Vegas! Upon entering the small restaurant, the environment felt very welcoming which is important to me. 

I ordered a bowl of miso ramen, while my boyfriend ordered the shio ramen. It took only about 5 minutes for our two bowls of hot ramen to arrive at our table. From the moment my ramen touched the table I could smell the delicious chashu pork and hearty broth. The chashu pork was very flavorful and soft compared to some ramen places I've been to where its been chewy and dry. The noodles were a little thick and slightly chewy, but well cooked. Both of us were very satisfied with our meal and definitely will come back again.

Tips: For those who have a preference for a more subtle taste , order the shio. It is very light and not too salty or too overwhelming for flavor. The miso on the other hand is loaded with flavor, so choose wisely!

The quote I used for my summary occurs about halfway through THE GOOD EARTH, as a captain of a Chinese revolutionary army (played by Philip Ahn) apologizes to a mob for not having time to shoot MORE of the looters among them, as his unit has just been called back to the front lines. Of course, the next looter about to be found out and shot is the main character of the film, the former kitchen slave girl O-Lan (for whose portrayal Luise Rainer, now 99-years-old, won her second consecutive best actress Oscar).The next scene finds O-Lan dutifully delivering her bag of looted jewels to her under-appreciative husband, farmer Wang Lung (Paul Muni), setting in motion that classic dichotomy of a man's upward financial mobility being the direct inverse of his moral decline.For a movie dealing with subject matter including slavery, false accusations, misogyny, starvation, home invasion, eating family pets, mental retardation, infanticide, exploited refugees, riots, civil war, summary mass street executions, bigamy, child-beating, adultery, incest, and insect plagues of biblical proportions, THE GOOD EARTH is a surprisingly heart-warming movie.My parting thought is in the form of another classic quote, from O-Lan herself (while putting the precious soup bone her son has just admitted stealing from an old woman back into the cooking pot after husband Wang Lung had angrily tossed it to the dirt floor on the other side of their hut): "Meat is meat."

We stayed here 2 nights in September for a wedding. I've stayed here before and I am always very happy with the service, this time was no different. I admit that there may be better places to stay in the city, certainly the parking is atrocious and you will pay $50 a day to park your car there, but that is San Francisco. I had an ulterior motive for staying here: shopping! But that is the beauty of this hotel, you can make many, many trips to the mall on foot. Shop in the morning, bring your loot back to the hotel, take a break, go back at it...well you get the idea. And the shopping was fabulous, so much so that now I probably can't afford this hotel as all of my money is wrapped up in my new winter boots. Rooms are updated and clean, I like the green option at this westin, choosing not to clean your room will get you $5 a day or 500 spg points. Our room was overlooking a church, and I actually liked hearing the churchbells in the morning but realize that may not be for everyone. The other bonus, their gym is AMAZING. Maybe it's because I work out at a pit at home, but I loved this gym! Everything was new, which made working out more fun, and who doesn't like a fun workout?! Overall, this is a very good hotel in the city, a cab ride away from anything you might want to do.
Caveat: I did pay with points so I can't speak to the value of the hotel.

The restaurant has a variety of dishes on their menu, but their main attraction is the pork ribs. If you have been to both the restaurants in Bali (Ubud & Seminyak), you will soon realize that the ribs here taste way better. The ribs are well cooked and moist (not burnt), the chili dipping is exceptionally good, which you don't get in Bali and the plating is unique. Other dishes are equally delicious, for example, the sup buntut, maggie goreng and also their duck confit-asian style are just some of the must try. The price is reasonable for the portion and the flavours. It is great because you get to have a piece of Bali. Service is also excellent. The staff have an entertaining dance, which is lively and i've seen some guest join in. Its great fun. A must visit place for pork ribs.

We stayed at the Drury Plaza on a recent trip to San Antonio. We absolutely loved everything about it. We had booked a standard 2 queen room through hotels.com. We received a very good rate that averaged about 120.00 a night.
Rooms--Our room was located in the older section that was once the bank building. We had a huge corner room. It had six windows and we could see most of San Antonio including the riverwalk. Although the carpet seemed to be worn, the bathroom appeared to be newly remodeled. The beds were extremely comfortable and had a pillow-top type mattress. Yes the rooms were in an older section, but in our opinion the fact that they were older and historical were what gave them character.
Location--This hotel was within 20 minutes of the airport, right on the riverwalk, and within walking distance of any location in downtown San Antonio.
Food--The free breakfast and kickback were good for what we needed them for. The breakfast kept us full until lunch and the kickback was a good appetizer for dinner.
Staff--There was not one person we encountered either in the hotel or in the city who were not polite, friendly, and helpful.
We would recommend this hotel with flying colors and will definitely stay here again on our next visit to San Antonio.

Having not seen this film in about 20 years I am still impressed with it 's hard -hitting impact and stellar acting. Of course, one Mr. Mickey Rooney is indeed, INCREDIBLE in his role as the ring-leading "Killer".(In reference to another review here-none other than Orson Welles evoked Mickey Rooney's name as the greatest movie actor,also.) I also recall the jazzy-brassy score and the bare black and white photography. I love the Mick's last line before he goes out for his dose of lead poisoning.(I think the Stranglers lifted it for a line in one of their songs-Get a Grip on Yourself.)This is a great film and unjustly buried film. Let's get it out ! Side note-a recent Film Review magazine gave a big write up on Don Segal's "Babyface Nelson" ,made a couple years before "Last Mile" and also starring Mickey Rooney. Another rave of the Mick's intense and sympathetic performance.Perhaps it's the start of a groundswell of a appreciation for some truly superior cinematic performances.

Wohoo, Sales! This is not the biggest strenght of MEC, of course, but when it happen, it's not that much advertised but if you're looking at the right place, at the right momen, you're golden! MEC is most likely one of my favorite place to shop. In my top 4 for sure. I like books,music, traveling, outdoors' activities, cooking and eating. There's at lest 2 things that this store will help me with: Traveling and outdoor: Buying the good gear makes your life easier. Plus I don't like spending my money in stuff that suck. So here I am, going in to try the Trail Glove Merrell Barefoot shoes - which fit my large feet, yes!!! - but i also found my Gregory Mywok 22 liter Gourd-Bag. Regular price: 115$ yeah I know, not cheap, but got it for 79$! One thing i've noticed since the last time I went is that the way the store is now, is a bit different from last time and that they have way more paleo supplement, dry food. The store is just so ridiculously big. It takes a big chunk of your day if you want to explore the store in full. 

Tant mieux , des ventes! c'est pas la force de MEC, mais quand on regarde attentivement et qu'on cherche comme il faut on peut tomber sur de bonnes aubaines. C'est pas mal dans mes meilleures places pour magasiner. J'aime lire, la musique, le plein air et voyage, cuisiner et manger. Je peux m'équipé comme un chef pour avoir un quotidien plus facile et agréable. Je me suis acheté un sac-gourde Gregory qui vaut 115$ a 79$ méchante bonne aubaine! C'est vraiment un bon sac, 22 litres, avec gourde jusqu'a 3 litres. C'Est vraiment parce que j'n'avais pas de sac pour mettre mon lunch au début mais je dois admettre que ça a vraiment rendu le transport des bidules du quotidien plus agréable. Voyez-vous certains dudes sont du genre sacoche d'homme ou porte-feuille, moi c'est Sac-à-dos! Et y commence (enfin on vas espérer) à faire chaud, donc la gourde est primordial pour rester hydrater dans les chaudes journée d'étés!. 

Ils ont un peu changé la structure du magasin vs la dernière fois où j'y suis allé mais c'est bien organiser. Ils ont beaucoup augmenter le stock de nourriture de camping aussi je trouve. Enfin, un must pour le magasin de plein air. 

PS: Les mauvaises critiques sur le magasin ne justifie certainement pas d'avoir à faire du bashing sur la location. une personne a maltraité la location qui est au marché central. Soit, c'est nul y aller en bus ou à pied ou en métro, mais c'est loin d'être au milieu de nullepart.

Visiting Vegas anytime soon???? Leave the $9.99 rib-eye specials @ the strip. This place is worth the ride. KoMex is a small, quaint, family-run dive. But, your taste buds and wallet will thank you. We took a taxi(not recommended unless you schedule them to pick you back up) Nevertheless, we waited happily for 30 minutes chatting up on how great this meal was. In the end, taxi never showed and the owner Linda graciously offered us a ride back to our hotel. I've never rated on yelp before and this may just be the beginning of more to come. KoMex will be tough to beat on budget and value. I see a bright future ahead for these folks. THANKS AGAIN!

We first tried this place for the $30 restaurant week meal. The service was the best service I've ever had anywhere in Las Vegas and the food was great, but not without flaws here and there. We both enjoyed grumpy's salad (like a wedge salad but already chopped up for you!) and my trout was spectacular. My husband got the steak and it was pretty bad - chewy and nothing special. Dessert was beautifully presented and tasty (a chocolate flourless cake if memory serves). Overall a 4, but not a 5 star dinner. It was $30, however, and it WAS restaurant week, so I went back a few weeks ago determined to have the 5 star evening I was determined Todd's could deliver! 

Todd's had sent out an email about how they were one of a few restaurants to get one of the first early shipments of King Crabs this year. I'm a huge crab freak, so I was more than eager to try them. They were sold in 2 or 3 lb dinners at market price ($65ish if memory serves). My husband and I shared this and it was TONS of crab. My husband's family is from Maryland my family is from New Orleans so we're pretty big on crab. Most of the buffet crabs here I find pretty disgusting, and I was eager to have a crab dinner that lived up to my standards! The crab here was phenomenal. I've had king crab many times before but this was by far the best I'd ever had. This crab was fresh off the boat (just 2 days before!) and had never been frozen. Flavor and texture was flawless. I never thought I'd eat the best crab in my life in freaking Henderson, NV, but this happens to be the case !

Other than the mediocre steak during restaurant week, everything about this place has been flawless over our 2 visits. The decor is very dated, but the service and food more than make up for it!

This was my second trip to Chicago for a "girls getaway", but my first time at this hotel. The location was good, as it is more centrally located to common attractions, and only a very short walk to the bus stop. However, I was disappointed that there was a $25 restocking fee for the refrigerator that was in the room, and a $20 fee if we wanted a refrigerator brought to the room to use. There was also a fee for the internet. For the price that we paid for the room, I would have thought these items would be included. The bathroom was tiny, and the sink/mirror was located inside the bathroom, meaning only one person could get ready at a time. The first day we were there we had an issue with our air conditioning. It ran all day and night, but wasn't blowing out cold air. Finally after turning it off and on, it began to blow out cold, but then stayed ice cold even after turning the thermostat up. (We were going to report it, but once it started blowing out cold air we were happy, so we didn't feel it was anything to complain about.) The fan on the AC was noisy, but it blocked out city noises. The hotel is next to a busy hospital, and there were constant sirens, but we were on the 33rd floor, so noise was not really an issue for us, but probably is on the lower floors. We did not eat in either restaurant because the prices were quite high. We noticed the price of the breakfast buffet was $17.95 per person, and I cannot imagine eating enough food to make it worth that price. On the plus side, the beds and pillows were extremely comfortable, and the best part of our stay. The staff was wonderful and very friendly and helpful. Overall, it was a nice clean hotel, but nothing fancy. The location was good for shopping, (but not much of a view), and I assume that is what we were paying for, as there were no amenities included. The less expensive (and just as nice) hotel that I stayed in last year included a refrigerator and free internet and we were directly across from Grant Park, so I would probably choose that location next time instead of this one.

One of my favorite places to get away and just experience nature. The preserve encompasses 17,000 acres, and the city is working to add thousands more acres in the next few years. Residents of the northeast part of Scottsdale and Fountain Hills are blessed with sweeping views of the McDowell Mountains every day. I am lucky enough to live in a neighborhood that borders the preserve, and try to take short hikes as often as possible.

The easiest way to access the preserve is via the Gateway Trailhead. Located off Thompson Peak, it provides ample parking and a very upscale visitor's center with clean bathrooms and maps. During peak times, volunteers are there to answer your questions and guide you on the appropriate trails.

A good introduction to the preserve is the Gateway Loop Trail, a moderate hike of 4.4 miles. The trail leads up to a saddle and then back down. I typically take the trail clockwise, so I encounter the steeper part first (1.7 miles up to the saddle). Great for trailrunners and mountain bikers, although parts of the incline are quite rocky. The Gateway Loop Trail offers access to the Bell Pass Trail and Windgate Pass Trail. I would recommend the Gateway Loop Trail to those in moderate shape. The flatter trails closer to the Gateway Trailhead, such as the Saguaro Loop Trail, are better for those out of shape or new to hiking. 

Here's a basic map of the trails in the preserve:
 <url> Tom's Thumb trailhead is currently understand construction, and the Brown's Ranch Trailhead will begin construction in 2012. If you want to check out the trails at Brown's Ranch before the new trailhead opens, just head east on Dynamite from Pima and turn left on Alma School Road. Follow it until it ends and park. You can navigate using the power lines, rock piles, and Brown and Cone Mountains. Here's a link to the current map offered by the city:
 <url>

The pros:
Great location nears many attractions and great restaurants
Provide great nightlife with good drinks and great music
The cons:
Snooty and unprofessional staff
Room cleanliness is questionable
Loud music until late hours
Uncomfortable bed
If they improve their service, I'd stay here again. If not, this hotel doesn't offer good enough service for the value.

This is a very nice hotel - a beautiful renovation in a city that needs good service and a good reputation - but we were extremely disappointed with our stay.
We had two incidents during our stay. The first was that a male staff member entered our room without knocking while we were in the room. The second incident was that our GPS system was stolen out of our glove compartment in our car. The valet service offered to replace the GPS, which was unexpected and appreciated. However, that does not change the fact that we can never trust the valets at this hotel and thus I am disappointed to say that we will never stay at this hotel again or recommend it to anyone.
What is most unfortunate is that this is about more than a room intruder and a stolen GPS. This is about the resurgence of Detroit. I have family in Grosse Pointe and am often in the area. My family and I are big fans of the D and are pulling for the city to shine again. I chose a night at the Westin as a 35th birthday gift to my husband (which was a major expense for me) and what was supposed to be a relaxing, rejuvenating night ended up being fraught with discomfort and disappointment. We are advocates for Detroit but how are we supposed to encourage our friends and family to spend time there if this was our experience? We simply cannot. And that makes me genuinely sad.

We were a group (6 couples) - first time visit to Chicago and chose to stay at the Palmer House. The hotel is in an excellent location, within walking distance to most major sites in the city. Originally we were booked in at the Drake, but found a great price, through Priceline.com . We called the hotel directly, tried Hilton Honours rates, but the best deal was through priceline.
The Palmer House is grand old beautiful hotel, and as most state on TripAdvisor, the rooms are quite small. All we were looking for was: location, comfortable, clean rooms. We were not disappointed.
A couple of helpful hints for first timers.
- shop around for prices, priceline was a huge savings.
- if you're coming from O'Hare, take the BlueLine subway. It's only $2.25, takes 40 minutes and get off at Monroe. The hotel is really close to the subway stop. Easy travelling both ways!
- if you are staying for a few days, get a day, 3 day or 7 day transit pass. The subway system is fantastic.
- 7th Floor is the business center. No charge to use. Print off your boarding passes in advance.
- The hotel is in the financial district, so it is quieter at night, but a lot of great restaurants and Jazz bars, short taxi ride away.
- Breakfast / coffee at the Corner Bakery restaurant (right beside the hotel) is great!
- There is a charge to use the Fitness /workout facilities, but no charge for the indoor pool.
- The original Chocolate Brownie (recipe) was created at the Palmer House (early 1900's). For a late night dessert try one in the lobby bar. Fantastic! Ask at the concierge and they will give you a copy of the recipe.
- drinks in the hotel $$$ !
- Chicago architecture boat tour was amazing. Very informative, gave great insight on the history of Chicago, and a excellent way to see the city and get your bearings.
Chicago, you have a very beautiful city. We will be back!
Excellent. This company properly trains the entire staff. On a comparison basis, it is no wonder as to why Singapore Airlines constantly and consistently ranks as number 1 or 2 or 3 in the world.

The hotels room come with a small kitchen that has a fridge, microwave, stove, dishwasher, and a toaster. The beds are very comfortable. Bathrooms are also decent. Nice touch is the sofa and chair that matches with the decor. It is not a dull room. However the hotel is at a location where it is not safe to go out after 6pm/sunset.
The restaurants in the neigborhood all shut down around 7pm or so. So your option is to have dinner at the Courtyard or Starbucks both of which are attached to the hotel building. A better option is to buy some microwave ready (heat and eat) kind of food and store it in the refrigerator unless you are a non-veg and can hit the social hour in the hotel lobby.
Hotel has buffet breakfast (fruit, bagels, breads, eggs, meats, and waffles) that is complimentary/self serve. Breakfast options are semi-decent. The only thing I would recoomend the hotel staff is to put couple more toasters - one to serve 40 to 50 people at peak time is not sufficient. They also have a evening social hour with some food, beer, juices, soda, and wine (all complimentary). If one is a non-veg, they can make a dinner out of this and don't have to worry about going out. Veg folks are out of luck - salad and some hamburger buns are what is uusally there. Hotel needs to start catering to the needs of the veg folks and veg means more than salad, This is my 2nd 10 day stay here and I have only seen veg option once (not too great looking). I would think they can have a lot of veg options and the simplest one might be cheese pizza or being in texas - tacos with beans.
Front desk folks greet you very well but it would be better if they understand the needs of their guests a bit better. The shuttle service could be a bit more frequent. It would be nice if the front desk can telll the travller when the shuttle would arrive rather than asking the travller to check around the corner. If this was a public shuttle, I would understand. But this is the hotel run shuttle.
Overall I think this is an OK place but with some improvements, it could be a desirable place to stay.

This HI Express is one of the best ones we have stayed at - very good location w/grocery store, fast foods, Cracker Barrel, gas stations etc within walking or short driving distance - would have been nice to have bananas available w/breakfast. Staff very accommodating and room outstanding with wonderful view overlooking a pond - only drawback was bad Wi Fi connection in room (none) and there was a loose faucet in sink next to microwave which I thought could have been fixed - we told mgr. the night of arrival - or at least a note saying it would be looked at later -makes me wonder if it will !! Overall, I was very impressed and would recommend it and stay there again.

When work is looking like a crap day, all I need is a sandwich from here, or a salad to put me back in a good mood. The greek salad with chicken to be exact.

Subs sandwiches are served toasted on really good bread rolls. The tuna is one of my favs.

There isn't a lot of seating but enough. It can get busy around lunch time so I always recommend going for a late lunch--- around 1/1:30pm.

Stayed for a weekend in early May - everything was as reviewed here - accomodations are fine, if a little unusual (note to conservatives, you may not like the decor). Staff was very friendly. We requested a room on a high floor and it was delivered. No problems with noise. Good location for getting to the metro, everything is just a few stops from DuPont Circle. If you can get a copy of the AAA Guide, the free parking coupon for the Topaz will save you about $50.

This hotel was in good condition and the rooms were nice and clean and we were fortunate enough to get a high-floor room with a nice panoramic view of the City. The staff was quite helpful and motivated to provide good customer service. My only (minor) complaints would be the hotel's relative isolation and lack of walking-distance amenities (restaurants, cafes, shopping, etc). In exchange for this isolation, you have easy access to the #29 bus which goes up State Street, through downtown and conveniently ends at the Navy Pier. We bought a 3-day CTA pass for $14 and it was a great value for seeing Chicago and getting to/from the hotel.
Good service and very kind

So after I finished reading Burn for Me, the first book in Ilona Andrews’ new and AMAZING Hidden Legacy series, I got to talking with another Ilona fan, who had been told that the world-building in Burn for Me was similar to the worlds in the Kinsmen series and the novella, Of Swine and Roses.And I was like, “Huh. I can see that.” But it’d been years since my early OMG-I-LOVE-Ilona binge, so I decided a reread was in order.And here we are.Some time in the indeterminate future, when space colonization was the new Big Thing, humans began to genetically enhance themselves. They needed to be stronger, faster, heartier, more versatile. Some of these enhancements were tech-based, effecting only the individual, and some were biological, being inherited by offspring."It was quickly realized that the advantage of these biological enhancements lay in their exclusivity. Thus, the biologically enhanced united and shut down all further biological modification."And consolidated their power. They were called the Kinsmen, and to maintain both the potency and exclusivity of their enhanced blood, the families arranged marriages for their children based on bloodlines and business alliances.This is why Meli Galdes was betrothed to Celino Carvanna when she was 10 years old and he was 16.While neither of them was happy with the arrangement, Meli accepted it, but Celino did NOT. He worked the next 6 years to make himself indispensable to his family, and worth more as an individual than the alliance with the Galdes family.And he succeeded.But where did that leave Meli?An excellent question. And one you will only get the answer to by . . . wait for it . . . yes, that’s right—READING the book. *winsome face*Verdict: a quick, fun, and SEXY read. Yes, I know it’s Ilona Andrews, and yes, I know that fabulous as she is, she’s not particularly well known for sexy times, but there’s a first for everything, right? Highly recommended.

The Drake is beautiful. The staff was fantastic. The room was amazing. I arrived early in the day and was able to go right to my room. I wasn't happy with the view from my first room, and when Jeffrey from the front desk called me to see how I liked my room, I told him this and he was able to move me to the same type of room (corner room) but on a higher floor. The room was very clean and the view was great.
My only issue with the hotel was that I was on the 19th floor and there is a club on the 21st floor. After 8:30, all I heard was music and bump bump noise. It was terrible!! If you like quiet, make sure you stay on a lower floor. I am sure they could have moved me had I asked, but that was the last thing I wanted to do at 10:30 PM. I called to see if they had earplugs and had a pair at my door within 5 minutes.
Overall, very happy with my experience.

Excellent location near riverwalk without being in the middle of the crowds and traffic. Easy access by walking or driving. Quiet. Hotel was super clean, proffessional staff, very helpful, rooms were huge!!! Cost affordable, would definetely recommend.

we have just returned from a 5 day stay in the astor on the park, the staff were excellent,however we did have problems with the toilet in our room, but in all fairness the staff came to the rescue straight away Enrique was a hero!! the problem was not fixed so they moved us to another room which was no problem but we found the room too hot so we had to ask for the heating turned down, the room was very basic, but also very clean,and clean linen every day...we felt that it was a little out of the way,but could get the subway to where ever we wanted to go ,although i would not use them at night...we really enjoyed our stay in new york,and would go back to the astor,value for money.........

Very close to our Hotel, we just happened to pass by, recognising the name from Trip Advisor research. We were one of 2 couples the first night...and couldn't have been treated better, food was great, explained with passion by our host Soloman. Hailing from inland Bario, he gave us some insight into the food. The Wildflower Salad was STUNNING...and really ejoyed the Shreeded Beef and Chicken with herbs. Very reasonably priced food, cold beer and in a nice clean restaurant. Enjoyed it so much, took another couple with us 2 nights later...same result. Nice intimate place, close to Kuching Waterfront, Hilton and the Pullman. Would relish the chance to go here again..worth supporting

Ordered Monday 2pm. Delivered by Royal Mail (free postage) Tuesday 9.30 am. Installed and up and running by 10am. What a difference to performance. Thank you Mr Memory, you have saved my laptop from an early end.

This was a vacation for me and my wife and I choose this particular flight because of the departure and arrival timing. I set a countdown on my phone once the flight took off to ensure we knew when we needed to shutoff the inflight entertainment. This works really well and we felt rested and ready to explore SFO once we landed.
The seats were pretty comfortable and the cabin service was great as expected from SQ. However, the seat adjustment was a problem for my wife as it was pretty stiff and this is probably because it was a new plane. The food selection was great but taste-wise, we felt it was underwhelming. On our return flight, we decided to try out the "Book the Cook" menu instead and we felt the meals tasted a lot better.

We only had a couple of days to explore the city and I'm glad we opted to stay here. This has none of the tackiness of Fisherman's Wharf and there's great shopping and cable cars nearby. The rates were reasonable and the rooms We had a car with us, but only needed it when wanting to travel outside the city. If you want to avoid the valet parking at the hotel, there's a very reasonable alternative across the street for $21. The only downside to our room was we didn't have any armchairs, just the single desk chair -- although there was plenty of room for some! As there were two of us in the room, we had to sit on the bed. We didn't have time to sample the hotel's amenities, such as restaurants or gym; we were out exploring the city.

Had a short vacation in Philly to see some friends a few days ago and stayed here at Hotel Palomar, the location is ideal, you're within walking distance of many attractions. The staff is very welcoming and nice and is willing to give advice on places to go and sorts. Definitely staying here next time we are in town!

My parents and I stayed in a 3-person room, with one double and one twin bed, for 2 nights. The room was rather small, but we were prepared for it. There was air-conditioning, which was great to protect us from the 90+ temperatures outside. The ensuite bathroom was convenient, and the shower worked fine. Towels and bedlinen were changed as expected. At $135 a night (before tax), the price was OK for mid-June.
Hotel 31 is situated very close to the Empire State Building, and 15 minutes walk from Times Square. This was excellent, as we could explore all of midtown Manhattan on foot within a couple of hours.
There was one problem: the elevator within the building stopped working for at least 45 minutes on the morning of the second day, so my parents and I had to walk up 6 storeys to our room. Luckily the (tiny) elevator was walking when we checked in and checked out, so we didn't have to carry our luggage up and down.
The front-desk people were helpful, and recommended a good diner for breakfast.

It is extremely difficult finding a honest, knowledgeable, reasonably priced mechanic. You will usually get one out of the three with most being dishonest, money hungry scavengers trying to fulfill a quota, IMO. Highline has been and continues to be an awesome experience each time. Strange for an Auto Shop right? I was referred to Highline Auto by a fellow Officer after I shared how I went to Midas and was advised that they were unable to do my oil change because the oil pan or cap was damaged? Or they couldn't unscrew it? Confusing right? It should be noted I went in with a coupon for a $16.99 oil change. I am now sure that this was the ticket to get me in the door, to be followed by a super duper up sale on items I didn't need. Suffice to say, I then took my car to Wes, didn't mention what happened at Midas and he proceeded to change my oil without a hitch! That set the tone and I have been taking my car to Highline Auto ever since. Highline doesn't need coupons. Wes and his mechanics treat you fairly, are knowledgeable, honest and friendly. You just can't beat that in this day and age! Highly Recommended

This is a Vietnamese rice noodle restaurant that deserves recognition in Johor!! The workmanship of the Vietnamese president and staff is very good~ I am sure it will not be a disappointment to recommend to anyone

i dont know why i didn't fall in love with pita jungle sooner. 

i work right next to the mall so the food court is super convenient for us. let me tell you a story of how i ate here everyday for lunch for a week. 

i ordered a standard gyro with no pickles (they put pickles on their gyros and i find that disgusting) 
my coworker, jen, ordered the pasta salad with chicken on top. 

mine was delicious and i tasted hers. hers was so good! i was like, that's what i'm ordering tomorrow.

the next day we went again and i ordered the chicken pasta. while waiting for the food to come out someone in front of me picked up their order of a hummus trio with chicken on top and a side of pita.

the next day jen asked where i wanted to go to lunch. i said pita jungle and i got my hummus trio. 

and the trend continued. their food is so good!!!! and its like $8!! and since i work nearby i get a discount! 

today i had a side of chicken breast with super fresh mushrooms. i watched them steam them, then put them in a pan with w tons of garlic, red wine, and seasoning. some of the best mushrooms i've ever had and it was a HUGE order of mushrooms.

We stayed here last here for The Miracle Ride and came back again this year. The rooms were clean and a decent size for the price. It is conveniently located within walking distance to food and other amenities. I really loved the window seat.

My daughter and I stayed here for 4 nights on our first trip to San Francisco. We arrived just before 1pm but were advised that our room wouldn't be ready until 3pm. That is the official check in time so understandable but after flying from Aus we just wanted a shower! Our bags were stored for us and we went for a walk around for a while and when we returned reception asked if we would like to use the business centre so we were able to send emails home while we waited for our room to be ready. Our room was a good size with 2 comfortable queen size beds. The wardrobe appeared to be a door to an adjoining room so I am wondering if a previous reviewer missed this and thought there was no wardrobe. All staff including our cleaner were very helpful and friendly. The location of the hotel is brilliant. So many diners, restaurants and shops nearby. We caught the streetcars on Market st to pretty much everywhere we needed to go for only $2. The only issue with the hotel was the noise! We had a Powell St facing room and I had very little sleep over the 4 nights. The cable cars stop at midnight and we didn't get to bed before then so they weren't a problem but the street noise from people and cars goes on through the night as does the construction work across the road - they were hammering floorboards etc right through the night and it sounded as though they were in the room with us. This was my only complaint and not something the hotel can do anything about.

Love them but will stain
These are very durable, handle being hand washed and dishwasher cleaned well (haven't but into washing machine out of inconvenience). The patterns are super cute also and they significantly reduce the number of disposable baggies I use. I put Cheez-its in the confetti pattern bag and the zipper fabric stained during the morning, I'm very disappointed in that but they are still great baggies for all ages.

Best expereince of my life!! Me and my husband have made it a thing to go to a show everytime we go to vegas. Weve seen quite a few of shows but blue man group takes the cake. We purchased our tickets from those trucks on the strip tix 4 tonight. We got a really good deal. 120 for 2 tickets and the seats were perfect. I recommend this to everyone. It really is magnificant. There are no words to describe it you just have to go. Its lively, its fun, and youll be talking about it forever. Great for kids too. \n\nLike 10 minutes before the show, they do this mini show around the casino and stops at the theatre. Its really wonderful i really have no words for it just go and see for yourself.

During my week in Chicago I stayed at 3 different Hotels in different areas of Chicago. The Allegro Hotel was the only disappointment during the entire trip.
Before I made reservations, I called the hotel and asked if the rooms were large enough for 3 people to fit comfortably and the answer was yes, definately. I booked the room for 4 people and even paid a little extra - $249.00 per night thinking that I would get a larger rooms/suites. Let me tell you how small my room was - 2 double beds tight up against each wall with a 3 1/2 ' desk/nightstand in between the beds. The room also had only a 19" TV in an armoire. Very, very small bathroom, pedestal sink - with a small shelf above with hardly any room to put makeup or toiletries.
This room was described as being "art deco" and it really wasn't except for a couple lamps. It was just shabby and in need of some "life". The worst part - My room had a locked adjoining room door. This door was not sound proof at all. I constantly heard my neighbors TV or their conversations and could even heard them using the bathroom and the loud flush of their toilet. I had to leave my TV on low vaolume all night long just to drown out the noise.
Somehow my room didn't get cleaned during my 2 night stay - that was OK though since my expectations were now so low. We made our own beds and just requested towels and toiletries.
To be fair, the hotel is clean, in a fun area and has pleasant employees. It has a grand lobby, restaurant and wine/beer reception. However, I don't get too many vacations and when I do I want what I asked for and paid for. I found this hotel a big disappointment.

You seat in the beach, with the sound of sea waves as background. Just perfect!

For what we would pay for a regular room in a more "upscale" chain, we had a king suite, with lots of room. It would easily and comfortably accomodate a couple with one or two kids. The location was perfect; lots to do. The hotel is well done, with lots of attention to the decor and furnishings. We ate one breakfast in the hotel restaurant and the food was very good. We noted that some people complained about noise from next door rooms but we heard nothing at all (and the hotel was busy). We had a room on the main street and also did not think it was noisy (the windows provide good sound proofing). Not just a good value but a good hotel.
This location is very nice and the staff is awesome i would definitely return to this location if i ever needed to stay downtown phoenix area

Been to Cibo many times! Beautiful historic house, consistently great service, best pizza in the Valley. We have long-debated whether Cibo surpassed Bianco, but I no longer question that it does. Cibo is best, and reasonably priced and delicious. The burrata is also the best I have ever had, and I highly recommend it. It is extremely creamy, but holds together very well, and the balsamic drizzled across the top is phenomenal.
We had a good time. Good food. The oxtail soup was superb. Thank u Nik, Ruben & Syafika for taking care of our night...Shall come back.... soon.

We came back for the fajitas......and weren't disappointed at all!

The fresh chips, salsa and beans, and grilled onions & peppers were delicious and a great way to start the evening.
We both ordered the fajitas for two with pork and chicken. My pork was packed with flavor, tender, and most amazing. I'm totally not a fajita kind of guy, but you give me this place as an option; We'll be back!
